citeinfo.origin: Rice, K.G., J.H. Waddle, M.E. Crockett, R.R. Carthy, and H.F. Percival
citeinfo.title: Herpetofaunal Inventories of the National Parks - Virgin Islands

descript.abstract: The Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) requires the use of ecological indicators to measure the success of restoration efforts. The Everglades amphibian community is ideal because amphibians are present in all habitats and under all hydrologic regimes. During Everglades restoration, hydrologic patterns will change and the response of ecological indicators will determine success. Fourteen amphibian species were detected through VES, vocalization surveys and trapping methods throughout the study and the occurrence information collected in this project database.
descript.purpose: Collect baseline data on the status of amphibian populations in Big Cypress National Park.

spdom.descgeog: Virgin Islands National Park, Florida, USA

idinfo.accconst: The original dataset contains many fields with information such as environmental variables, observers/collectors, and field notes associated with each record. Use the 'Point of Contact' in this document for a complete list of, and to gain access to, fields associated with this subset of the original dataset.
idinfo.datacred: Kenneth G. Rice, J. Hardin Waddle, Marquette E. Crockett, Raymond R. Carthy, and H. Franklin Percival
idinfo.native: Data stored in Microsoft Access Database named "dbVirginIslandsv2.0.mdb"

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing sample collection environmental variables

attr.attrdef: The unique primary key value automatically assigned by access for each sampling occasion
The same as the TransectID field from the tblTransectInformation
The date on which the transect was sampled
The sample period (1= Feb 2001; 2= Oct. 2001, 3=May 2002)
The time at which the transect was begun
The time at which the transect was completed
Air temperature in celsius to one decimal place.
The % relative humidity of the air at the start of the transect sample
The temperature of any standing water encountered along the transect
The category of the weather conditions

edom.edomvd: Weather conditions different than the above choices

attr.attrdef: The category of wind speed
The ID of all observers present when double observer method was not used
Whehter or not the perpendicular distance from the edge of the trail was measured.
Whether or not the dual observer method was used
The initials of the primary observer for this transect
The intials of the secondary observer
Any notes about the individual sample
The unique identifier within this database that relates the plot information to the samples and observations.

enttyp.enttypd: table contains information about the species recorded in the database

attr.attrdef: The three letter code name assigned to each species. The first letter is the first letter of the genus, the second two letters are the first two letters of the specific epithet, unless this causes a duplicate anbd then modifications are made when necess.
The taxonomic class to which the species belongs (Repttilia, Amphibia)
The taxonomic order/suborder to which the species belongs.
The taxonomic family to which the species belongs.
The genus to which the species belongs.
The specific epithet of the species.
The subspecific epithet of the species if applicable.
The accepted common name of the species (From Maclean 1982).
Whether or not the species is considered introduced (exotic) on St. John.

edom.edomvd: Species is introduced to this area
Species is not introduced to this area

attr.attrdef: Whether this species was detected during this study.

edom.edomvd: Species was detected during this study.
Species was not detected during this study.

attr.attrdef: Any notes about the species and it's occurence on St. John.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing visual encounter survey data

attr.attrdef: The primary key field, assigned automatically by Access
The same as the SampleID field in the tblTransectSamples, this is used to relate the data here to the location and weather data
Relates to the SpeciesCode field in tblSpeciesList, where the whole name of the species is listed
Whether the sex of the animal was male, female, or undetermined
Whether the animal was an egg, larva, juvenile, sub-adult, or adult
The snout to vent length of the animal in mm
The heigth of the animal above the ground where it was discovered
The type of substrate on which the animal was found
The distance perpendicular from the edge of the trail to the animal along the ground. Used for distance analysis
Whether or not the individual was observed by the primary observer
Any notes about the individual animal
